chargeHist.descr: Take and Drive Vehicle w/o Consent

result.execSummary:
The defendant Darionta D Phifer was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case. One or more other charges in this case were dismissed. The dismissed charges were not proven and have no legal effect. Darionta D Phifer is presumed innocent of the dismissed charges.

  • Darionta D Phifer was found guilty of Take and Drive Vehicle w/o Consent, a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.23(2).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes:
Court costs due during first 6 months of probation. Defendant to arrange payment plan with agent.
Pay supervision fees.
  If probation is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, in addition to all other enforcement sanctions available to the court, a civil judgment enforceable by all creditors' remedies shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and governmental entities for the balance due.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

superMiscConds.notes: Fines, costs, and restitution are due during term of supervision.  Court further orders 25% of prison wages to be applied toward Court ordered financial obligations.  If defendant is released with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment enforceable by all creditors' remedies shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and governmental entities for the balance due.
Court costs due during the first 6 months of extended supervision. Defendant to arrange payment plan with agent and pay supervision fees.
No contact with Mary Ellen Haas.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea
